Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness by not informing the applicant of Ethiopia's directive
Application_Facts: Applicant consulted the Ethiopian Department for Immigration in October 2004; knew about Ethiopia's directive prior to submission
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa application rejection
Court_Ruling: No breach of procedural fairness occurred
Defendant_Behavior: Immigration officer did not inform applicant of Ethiopia's directive
Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived durable solutions in Ethiopia leading to visa rejection
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of evidence unknown to the applicant
Assessment_Factor: Whether the evidence was publicly available or extrinsic to the applicant
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose information during immigration assessment
Review_Standard: Standard of procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Legal_Provision_Cited: Procedural fairness under administrative law principles
Evidence_Assessed: Applicantâ€™s prior knowledge of Ethiopian immigration policy
Governing_Rule: Publicly available information does not require formal disclosure under procedural fairness
Cause_Description: Applicant's permanent resident visa application was rejected due to perceived durable solutions in Ethiopia
Evidence_Handling: No obligation to disclose information already known to applicant
Evidence_Issues: Whether the directive constituted extrinsic evidence requiring disclosure
Legal_Provision: Procedural fairness obligations under administrative law
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant had prior knowledge, so no unfairness in non-disclosure
Decision_Rationale: The applicant was aware of the Ethiopian directive before submission; thus, no breach of procedural fairness
Evidentiary_Issues: Nature and accessibility of the Ethiopian directive
